awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Coordination Chemistry of Zinc-Chelating S100 Proteins and Biochemistry Partnership with a Regional University
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Elizabeth M. Nolan from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to study the zinc-binding properties of several human metal-chelating proteins that are implicated in physiological processes that include inflammation, the innate immune response, cardiovascular disease, and carcinogenesis. Protein biochemistry, analytical biochemistry including thermodynamic measurements, and various spectroscopic techniques are employed to characterize the zinc binding sites and measure the affinity for zinc of these proteins. In education and outreach, a biochemistry partnership between the Nolan Laboratory and the Department of Chemistry at Framingham State University is established with the long-term goals of (i) improving undergraduate biochemistry research and mentoring at Framingham State University (FSU) and (ii) increasing the numbers of FSU biochemistry concentrators continuing on to graduate school in the chemical/biochemical sciences. To integrate research and education, FSU faculty and students learn protein purification techniques and conduct biochemistry research in the Nolan Laboratory, and develop a protein purification laboratory manual. 

Zinc is a metal ion that is essential for many processes of life. The basic research developed with this award provides molecular-level insight into a family of human zinc-binding proteins and into the contributions of these proteins to zinc homeostasis in humans. The research and outreach activities provide training in the scientific method, research, and communication of science to a diverse group of undergraduate and graduate students from MIT and elsewhere. MIT graduate students mentor undergraduates from FSU, which is an important component of graduate education and training. These activities serve the local community by enhancing biochemistry at a regional university and motivating FSU students to continue studies and pursue careers in the chemical sciences.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
With this CAREER Award supported by the Chemistry of Life Processes program, Professor Nolan from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology investigated how two abundant human proteins, calprotectin (S100A8/S100A9 oligomer) and psoriasin (S100A7), interact with zinc. These proteins are physiologically abundant and are implicated in a range of human (patho)physiological conditions that include infectious and cardiovascular diseases, the inflammatory response, and cancer. Numerous prior studies indicated roles for these proteins in zinc biology, and deciphering how these proteins interact with zinc ions at a molecular level is necessary for understanding how these human proteins contribute to zinc homeostasis in both physiological and pathological states.

Intellctual Merit: The Nolan lab identified and evaluated an unusual zinc-binding site in calprotectin, which informed how this protein interacts with zinc in vivo and functions in the innate immune response. They also described the zinc-binding and cysteine redox properties of psoriasin, which provided a new model for how the protein responds to its local redox environment and coordinates zinc. Biochemical, analytical and spectroscopic approaches were utilized throughout these studies. In total, the research provides methods and a comprehensive framework for further chemical and biological initiatives that probe the roles of between calprotectin, psoriasin and other S100 proteins in the biology of transition metal ions.    

Broader Impacts: The Nolan lab has collaborated with the Department of Chemistry and Food Science at Framingham State University (FSU) to provide summer research opportunities to undergraduate students interested in biochemistry, to give panel discussions at FSU with the goal of educating FSU undergraduates about graduate school opportunities and career paths in the chemical sciences, and to engage in scientific outreach targeted at K-12 learning to the broader community.  


Last Modified: 04/14/2019
Modified by: Elizabeth M Nolan
